context: For the low-floor apartments, the median concentrations of the three VOCs for the nighttime samples (MTBE, 6.1μg/m3; benzene, 7.7μg/m3; and toluene, 36.9μg/m3) were consistently 1.2–1.4 times higher than those for the daytime samples (MTBE, 4.5μg/m3; benzene, 6.2μg/m3; and toluene, 25.9μg/m3). For the high-floor apartments, the median concentrations of the three VOCs for the nighttime samples (MTBE, 5.1μg/m3; benzene, 4.8μg/m3; and toluene, 24.8μg/m3) were consistently 1.3–1.4 times higher than those for the daytime samples (MTBE, 4.0μg/m3; benzene, 3.5μg/m3; and toluene, 19.8μg/m3). Moreover, for all the target compounds, the indoor air concentrations for the nighttime samples were significantly higher than those for the daytime samples for both low- and high-floor apartments, with a P value of less than or close to 0.05 (P<0.09 for the o-xylene level for low-floor apartments). The current study found that both the outdoor and the indoor air concentrations of three VOCs (MTBE, benzene, and toluene) were higher for low-floor apartments than for high-floor apartments, indicating that residents of low-floor apartments are exposed to elevated residential levels of these compounds compared to high-floor apartment residents.

Their mention is coincidental, as they are part of a broader discussion on VOC levels in residential settings.
